basic.title: Primary objective
basic.description: What is the primary purpose of locale testing?

options.text: To conduct copy checks to ensure that either, no English remnants are present after translation or remnants of other languages do not appear
options.outcome: Correct! This is the fundamental purpose of locale testing, encompassing language, rendering, and market-specific adaptations

options.text: To test the website's performance in different countries
options.outcome: While location may play a role, performance testing is a separate testing discipline.

options.text: To verify translations are grammatically correct
options.outcome: While translation verification is part of locale testing, it's only one aspect of the broader scope.

options.text: To ensure the website loads quickly in different regions
options.outcome: Website loading speed is part of performance testing, not locale testing.

basic.title: Documentation
basic.description: What type of documentation might clients provide for locale testing?

options.text: The client will provide server logs to assist in this type of testing
options.outcome: Server logs are not typically used for locale testing.

options.text: Copy deck or translations matrix can be submitted by the client
options.outcome: Correct! These are the primary reference documents provided by clients for verifying correct translations and content.

options.text: Design specifications can be provided to assist with locale testing
options.outcome: While design specifications might be provided, they're secondary to translation documents.

options.text: Network traffic data can be submitted to assist with locale testing
options.outcome: Network data is not relevant for locale testing.

basic.title: Characteristics of locale testing
basic.description: Which of the following is a key characteristic of locale testing?

options.text: Locale testing requires programming knowledge
options.outcome: Programming knowledge is not a primary requirement for locale testing.

options.text: Locale testing requires a keen eye for detail to spot minuscule variances
options.outcome: Correct! Attention to detail is important, especially for diacritics and subtle differences.

options.text: Locale testing requires fluency in all supported test languages
options.outcome: While language knowledge is helpful, testers can work with a translation matrix.

options.text: Locale testing requires network engineering expertise
options.outcome: Network engineering is not related to locale testing.

basic.title: Locale currency testing
basic.description: When conducting locale testing, what should testers check regarding currencies?

options.text: The currency symbol placement should be checked exclusively
options.outcome: While this is part of currency localisation, it's just one aspect of currency-related checks.

options.text: Exchange rates between currencies should be tested
options.outcome: Exchange rate verification is not part of locale testing.

options.text: Currency updates based on selected market under test
options.outcome: Correct! Verifying that currencies update appropriately for each market is part of locale testing

options.text: Currency conversion calculations need to be tested for accuracy
options.outcome: Mathematical currency conversions are not part of locale testing

basic.title: Locale test scripts
basic.description: What is a recommended practice for organising locale test scripts?

options.text: Random sections across different locales can be tested to gain the most coverage possible
options.outcome: This unstructured approach would not ensure comprehensive coverage.

options.text: Create separate scripts for each feature to be tested in regards to locale
options.outcome: While organisation is important, organising by locale first Is more efficient than organising the script on a feature basis.

options.text: Organise all locales to be combined into one test case
options.outcome: This would make testing confusing and difficult to track.

options.text: Separate each page or section to be tested by locale
options.outcome: Correct! This is the recommended organisation method and makes for easy tracking and traceability.

basic.title: Locale Testing Risks
basic.description: What is a potential risk of locale testing mentioned in the guide?

options.text: Testing could be affected by inaccuracies in client-provided translation documentation
options.outcome: Correct! Testing can be affected by the accuracy of client-provided documentation, especially translations where the tester is not a native speaker of the language under test.

options.text: Locale testing might expose security vulnerabilities
options.outcome: Security vulnerabilities are not a risk associated with locale testing and this type of testing is out of scope for locale test activities.

options.text: Testing multiple locales typically requires more resources than is available
options.outcome: While time constraints need to be managed, staffing shortages are not identified as a specific risk.

options.text: Locale testing often causes software to crash during language switches
options.outcome: Locale testing should ensure that content loads properly when changing languages but crashes as a result of switching languages is generally not common risk.

basic.title: Locale Documentation
basic.description: What document should testers consult to determine which locales are in scope for testing?

options.text: The locale test script template should be referred to for scoping
options.outcome: Test scripts don't define which locales are in scope, they're used to create the test scripts after scope is determined.

options.text: The tester's previous notes from similar projects should be referred to for scope
options.outcome: Previous notes might be helpful but should not be referred to as an authoritative source for determining which locales are in scope.

options.text: The client's Statement of Work and Operational Details documentation should be referred to
options.outcome: Correct! This documentation defines locales that are in scope and if there are any sub-areas within locale testing that are out of scope.

options.text: The global market trends report should be referred to for locale scope
options.outcome: Market trend reports should not be referred to as resources for determining testing scope as all clients have different requirements.

basic.title: Language Switch Testing
basic.description: What issue might occur when changing locales that testers need to specifically check for?

options.text: System crashes when switching languages
options.outcome: System crashes are not generally a common defect caused by locale switching.

options.text: Slow page load times need to be monitored when switching languages
options.outcome: Page load speed differences are generally part of performance testing.

options.text: Text truncation or overlapping content need to be monitored when switching languages
options.outcome: Correct! Identifying any rendering issues caused by word length when changing locales, such as overlapping content or lack of padding between page elements should be monitored.

options.text: Font colour changes should be monitored when switching languages
options.outcome: Font colour changes should not be a specific concern, although can be raised as a query unless stated as correct by the client documentation.

basic.title: Locale Test Consistency
basic.description: What important element should testers check consistently across locale changes?

options.text: Global elements such as header, navigation and footer should be checked
options.outcome: Correct! These elements should remain consistent when navigating the site on a selected locale.

options.text: Loading speed for each locale should be checked for consistency
options.outcome: While checking for any major issues in this area are recommended, loading speed is more aligned with performance testing.

options.text: The number of images displayed on each page
options.outcome: Whilst any major issues here should be reported. The amount of images would generally come under content and copy proofing.

options.text: Font size consistency across locales should be checked
options.outcome: While visual presentation is important, font size consistency isn't a specific check for locale testing. However, any major issues should be flagged.

basic.title: Locale Testing Advantages
basic.description: Which of the following is an advantage of locale testing?

options.text: It improves the user experience and customer satisfaction
options.outcome: Correct! Locale testing can identify issues with the presented language and therefore build confidence in the product from the user.

options.text: It ensures a universal experience across all regions
options.outcome: Locale testing is specifically designed to adapt software or content to different regions, not to make everything uniform.

options.text: It eliminates the need for native language testers
options.outcome: This would actually be considered as a limitation as not all testers will know multiple native languages.

options.text: It speeds up the loading time of the website in different regions
options.outcome: System performance is generally not associated with locale testing.

intermediate.title: Locale testing risk
intermediate.description: What potential risk is associated with locale testing when the tester isn't bilingual?

options.text: Certain incorrect translations may be missed even if in the correct language
options.outcome: Correct! This is a known risk as a tester may not know all languages under test.

options.text: The tester is unable to complete any testing due to lack of specialist knowledge
options.outcome: Non-bilingual testers can still perform many aspects of locale testing.

options.text: All testing needs to be outsourced to businesses providing locale specialists
options.outcome: Outsourcing is not necessary for locale testing as copy can be provided by the client to cross reference.

options.text: Basic language presence can be tested fully to completion
options.outcome: While they can verify language presence, they may miss nuanced translation errors.

intermediate.title: Right to Left languages
intermediate.description: How should right-to-left (RTL) language testing be approached?

options.text: Verify correct text rendering and layout adaptation
options.outcome: Correct! Checking rendering and layout for RTL languages is considered part of locale testing.

options.text: Test that the text direction is correctly presented
options.outcome: RTL testing involves more than just text direction like grammar and locale specific elements.

options.text: Test that the text alignment is correctly presented
options.outcome: While alignment is important, RTL testing requires comprehensive layout verification.

options.text: Ignore formatting elements as long as the local matches the copy submitted by the client
options.outcome: Formatting elements are crucial for RTL testing and include punctuation placement, number alignment and text alignment.

intermediate.title: Issue identification
intermediate.description: What is the recommended approach for handling issue identification across multiple locales?

options.text: Preface tickets with locale identifier (e.g., [FR], [ES])
options.outcome: Correct! This is the correct approach for ease of identification.

options.text: Create separate bug trackers for each locale
options.outcome: This would complicate issue management unnecessarily.

options.text: Report all issues as standard practice without locale references
options.outcome: This would make it difficult to track locale-specific issues.

options.text: Group similar issues that occur across different locales
options.outcome: While grouping can be useful, clear locale identification should be a primary objective.

intermediate.title: Validation messages
intermediate.description: What should testers verify regarding form validation messages?

options.text: That messages are translated and display correctly in each locale
options.outcome: Correct! This is a critical element for locale testing.

options.text: Check if validation messages appear when moving through the form
options.outcome: Merely checking presence is insufficient, actual correct message verification is also required.

options.text: Verify all validation messages are positioned correctly
options.outcome: While positioning is important, translation and correct display are primary objectives.

options.text: Verify all validation messages display on one environment
options.outcome: Validation messages and should be consistent across all environments.

intermediate.title: Time management
intermediate.description: How should testers manage time when testing multiple locales?

options.text: Balance testing across locales while maintaining thoroughness
options.outcome: Correct! The importance of time management across locales can ensure equal or priority coverage is met

options.text: Test focus should be solely worked through on a primary locale
options.outcome: All scoped locales require appropriate coverage.

options.text: Test one locale completely before moving to others
options.outcome: While thorough, this might not be the most efficient approach relating to project timelines and deliverables.

options.text: Conduct a random approach to testing of locales to gain the best coverage
options.outcome: Unstructured testing would not ensure the best coverage and priority areas need to be taken into consideration

advanced.title: Language remnants
advanced.description: What approach should be taken when testing for language remnants?

options.text: Check all user interface elements, including hidden states and validation messages
options.outcome: Correct! Comprehensive checking across all user interface elements is essential.

options.text: Check all main navigation features and headers throughout the system under test
options.outcome: While important, this is not comprehensive enough and other crucial elements can be missed.

options.text: Check all initial visible text on main pages
options.outcome: This could miss many potential issues like validation messages and sub pages.

options.text: Use automated translation detection for efficiency
options.outcome: Manual verification is necessary for thorough testing as automation doesn't always detect every issue.

advanced.title: Diacritic elements
advanced.description: How should testers handle diacritic elements during testing?

options.text: Verify correct rendering and meaning preservation
options.outcome: Correct! Diacritics must be checked for the importance of meaning.

options.text: Leave diacritical mark issues out of reports as they are not critical
options.outcome: This would miss crucial linguistic elements.

options.text: Test for presence of diacritics within all available text
options.outcome: Presence alone doesn't ensure correct usage or rendering.

options.text: De-scope diacritics when locale testing unless specifically requested
options.outcome: Diacritics can fundamentally alter the language and this should always be taken into consideration when testing locale.

advanced.title: Locale specific formatting
advanced.description: What strategy should be employed when testing locale-specific formatting?

options.text: Verify date, time, address, and phone number formats for each locale
options.outcome: Correct! These are all specific elements requiring verification

options.text: Use standard formats when testing across all locales
options.outcome: This would defeat the purpose of specific localisation testing.

options.text: Check date formats when performing locale testing
options.outcome: While important, this is only one aspect of formatting, other might include time or phone number formatting.

options.text: Check there are format variations, but leave format confirmation for different languages
options.outcome: Format verification is crucial for locale testing and should be cross referenced with copy provided by the client.

advanced.title: Text expansions
advanced.description: How should testers handle text expansion and contraction across different languages?

options.text: Verify layout integrity and check for truncation across all elements
options.outcome: Correct! Checking for truncation and layout issues is essential to locale testing

options.text: Test with maximum length text to check for truncation
options.outcome: This wouldn't catch all potential issues including layout integrity.

options.text: Ignore text length variations as long as elements can be successfully navigated
options.outcome: Text length variations can cause significant issues like layout integrity.

options.text: Check all visible elements across the system under test for truncation
options.outcome: While important, hidden states and dynamic content also need checking

advanced.title: Language selectors
advanced.description: What approach should be taken when testing language toggles and selectors?

options.text: Verify content updates, loading behaviour, and state preservation
options.outcome: Correct! It is important to check all these aspects of language switching.

options.text: Check for immediate visual changes under user input
options.outcome: While important, this doesn't cover all necessary aspects like actual content updates.

options.text: Verify that switching between languages occurs with user input
options.outcome: Testing this only can miss many important aspects of language switching including actual content correctness.

options.text: Ensure the system under test is responsive after switching languages
options.outcome: Whilst this is important, crucial contact accuracy could be missed if responsiveness is tested only.
